titleStmt.title: The Zurich 'Deutsche Schule' Inventory (1698), ed. by Claudio Bacciagaluppi, 2012 (Historical Music Inventories, ###)

publicationStmt.publisher: Swiss RISM Office, Université de Fribourg, Switzerland

msContents.summary: The music society 'zur deutschen Schule' was founded 1679 in Zurich. It merged in 1772 with the society 'zur deutschen Schule' into the society 'der mehreren Stadt', which in its turn was one of the two building in 1812 the 'Allgemeine Musik-Gesellschaft', still in existence today. The 'CONTINUATIO / Einer Lobl. Gesellschafft / der MUSIC Liebhaberen in der / Teütschen Schul Zum St. Peter / an dem Wolfs Bach in Zürich' (CH-Zz, AMG Archiv IV A 3) contain the protocols of the periodical general assemblies of the society in the years 1692–1707. On the pages 118-19 we find a list of some 40 titles. The origin of the inventory may be the most curious one encountered in Switzerland. In February 1698, the members had to admit a certain 'disorder' in the choice of the music to be rehearsed. The vice-kapellmeister Hans Kaspar Ziegler then compiled a list of the titles belonging to the music society, divided in three columns. At each rehearsal, one piece of music would have to be chosen from each column. This was a very simple but efficient method of obtaining both maximum variety, and a regular turnover in the performance of the repertoire at the society's disposal. Most importantly, it enables us to have an overview of the society's collection some twenty years after its foundation. The protocols of the assemblies before the compilation of the inventory sometimes offer help in identifing certain items: in fact, it is not unusual to find quite a complete transcription of the title at the moment of its acquisition, and only a very short title in the inventory proper.
